courses.name: TypeScript Fundamentals v3
courses.summary: Learn everything you need to know in order to confidently and successfully use TypeScript to build a modern JavaScript app.

courses.name: TypeScript Fundamentals v4
courses.summary: Learn everything you need to know in order to confidently and successfully use TypeScript to build a modern JavaScript app.

courses.name: Intermediate TypeScript v1
courses.summary:
Leverage TypeScript's strengths to provide clarity in the face of
complexity, while protecting your codebase and team from it's weaknesses.

courses.name: Intermediate TypeScript v2
courses.summary:
Leverage TypeScript's strengths to provide clarity in the face of
complexity, while protecting your codebase and team from it's weaknesses.

courses.name: Making TypeScript Stick
courses.summary:
Tackle a series of challenges designed to reinforce your knowledge and make
the important concepts truly "stick" in your mind.

courses.name: Enterprise-Scale TypeScript v2
courses.summary:
Learn how to manage large TypeScript code bases with confidence and ease.
In this course, Mike shares his knowledge from years of experience working
with teams who maintain TypeScript projects with hundreds of regular full-time
contributors and 100K+ lines of code.

courses.name: Full Stack TypeScript
courses.summary:
Combine TypeScript and GraphQL's type systems to create full-stack, fully
type-checked code bases that are shockingly easy to refactor and maintain.

useful and meaningful names: interfaces and type aliases. We will study both
concepts in depth, and explain when it makes sense to use each.

frontmatter.title: Conditional Types
frontmatter.description:
Conditional types can be thought of as "a ternary operator, for types".
While there is no "control flow" in a world where we're describing constraints with types
(instead of procedural steps to execute "in a flow"), this tool does provide
an important foundation for switching logic based on type information

frontmatter.title: Mapped Types
frontmatter.description:
Mapped allow types to be defined in other types through a
much more flexible version of an index signature. We'll
study this type in detail, and demonstrate how it makes
language features like indexed access types and conditional
types even more powerful!

frontmatter.title: Converting to TypeScript
frontmatter.description: Converting to TypeScript: Integrate TypeScript into your build, rename files to .ts, and incrementally enforce stricter types. Progressively refine type information, enhance function and class types, and reduce usage of any. Aim for methodical, incremental changes, backed by tests.

node.excerpt: In this chapter, we’ll follow steps 1, 2 and 3 as described in the approach for converting large projects from JavaScript to TypeScript. Get…

frontmatter.title: Steps 1, 2 and 3 - Adding our first types
frontmatter.description:
We'll tackle steps 1, 2 and 3 in the TypeScript conversion process, by integrating
TypeScript into our build tools, renaming our files to .ts, and getting rid of any
implicit any types. We'll use this as an opportunity to learn how this kind of change can be made in many small PRs over a long period of time, as is common in large projects.

frontmatter.title: Local Packages
frontmatter.description: We'll learn about yarn workspaces, and how they provide an opportunity for simple but effective modular architecture in a large TypeScript projects.

node.excerpt: Tests for types Why should we care? We need to do this for a couple of reasons: Type information is code too. Breaking your users’ types is…

frontmatter.title: Tests for Types
frontmatter.description: We'll look closely at how we can write tests for type information, including negative test cases for things we want to ensure do not compile.

pageContext.name: Making TypeScript Stick
pageContext.summary:
Tackle a series of challenges designed to reinforce your knowledge and make
the important concepts truly "stick" in your mind.
